borough: London Borough of Barking and Dagenham
decision_conditions: <div>The scale, siting and design of the proposed development are considered harmful to the appearance of the house, built form of the semi-detached pair and character of the area. The proposed development would disrupt the symmetry of the semi-detached pair which is on a prominent corner and adds to the quality of the street scene. The street scene would be further harmed through increased sense of enclosure and the proposal appearing overly intrusive.&nbsp; As such, the proposed development is contrary to:<br></div><div><br></div><div><p><span pt="" sans",="" sans-serif;"="" style="font-size: 10.5pt;">- Section 12 of the National Planning Policy Framework&nbsp;</span>National Planning Policy Framework (NPPF) (DLUHC, 2021) which promotes development that is high quality, attractive and adds to the quality of the area, and explicitly states development which is not well designed should be refused.&nbsp;<o:p></o:p></p><p class="MsoNormal"><span pt="" sans",="" sans-serif;"="" style="font-size: 10.5pt; line-height: 14.98px;">- Policy D4 of the London Plan (March 2021) which seeks to promote good design.&nbsp;<o:p></o:p></span></p><p><span pt="" sans",="" sans-serif;"="" style="font-size: 10.5pt;">- Policy CP3 of the&nbsp;</span>Local Development Framework (LDF) Core Strategy (July 2010) which seeks to achieve high quality design standards and strengthen local character.<o:p></o:p></p><p><span pt="" sans",="" sans-serif;"="" style="font-size: 10.5pt;">- Policy BP11 of the&nbsp;</span>Local Development Framework (LDF) Borough Wide Development Plan Document (DPD) (March 2011) which requires the design of buildings to protect the character of the area and provide high quality, attractive architecture.<o:p></o:p></p><p class="MsoNormal"><span pt="" sans",="" sans-serif;"="" style="font-size: 10.5pt; line-height: 14.98px;">- The Residential Extensions and Alterations Supplementary Planning Document (February 2012) which advises that extensions should respect the character of the existing dwelling and be of an appropriate scale, not appearing out of place when viewed as a part of the existing environment.<o:p></o:p></span></p><p class="MsoNormal"></p><p><span pt="" sans",="" sans-serif;"="" style="font-size: 10.5pt;">- Policies SP2, DMD1 and DMD6 of&nbsp;</span>The London Borough of Barking and Dagenham’s Draft Local Plan: (Regulation 19 Submission Version, December 2021) which promotes good design, expecting extensions to be respectful of the original character of the dwelling and local area and be acceptable within the street scene.&nbsp;</p></div>

The proposed development would have a harmful impact on the setting and special character of a Grade II Listed Building, as it would negatively impact the short and long views of this building from Denham Way.  As such, the proposed development is contrary to:

- Paragraphs 199-203 of the National Planning Policy Framework National Planning Policy Framework (NPPF) (DLUHC, 2021) which resists harm to heritage assets.

- Policy BP2 of the Local Development Framework (LDF) Borough Wide Development Plan Document (DPD) (March 2011) which aims to preserve the significance of listed buildings and their settings. 

- Section 4.3 of the Residential Extensions and Alterations Supplementary Planning Document (February 2012) which states that where extensions are located within the setting of a listed building, they will only be considered acceptable if they do not detract from the special character of the listed building. 

- Policy DMD4 of The London Borough of Barking and Dagenham’s Draft Local Plan: (Regulation 19 Submission Version, December 2021) which states that proposals affecting heritage assets must preserve the setting of the asset and its historic significance.
description: Construction of a single storey side extension.
